I am a father of 2 girls in a school district that is currently taking steps to implement a district wide (K-12) uniform policy. I decided to search the net to better educate myself on the pros and cons and get a sense of what results such a policy might have for my kids. Suffice it to say that I am not in favor of this new policy and the more I dig into the subject the less inclined I am to sit back and allow such a blind ambition to swallow my kids future school years.... and beyond.
 
 I have gone to a number of meetings and listened to many local views on why a school uniform policy should or shouldn't be enforced here in my daughters' schools. I have read feedback from parents on countless forums, recalled the speech by then president Clinton on school reform, had open heart to heart talks with both of my kids and read from cover to cover, the only scientific study published on the subject that I could find. I've done my homework so to say!! I have drawn (in large part to these scientific, non-bias studies) that uniform policies do very little if anything at all to actually meet the originally intended effects. 
 
 Instead it appears that they are being used as a "band-aid" for a number of other underlying problems. You cannot remove hatred from a 15 year old boy by changing his clothing!! You cannot curtail bullying by removing designer sneakers from the school. These are behavioral issues that result either from poor parenting, mental instability or lack of discipline within the school. All of which should be dealt with directly, not ignored by enforcing conformity instead. It is a dis-service to the individual student that needs, in fact is crying out for, extra assistance.
 By implementing a uniform policy we simply shift the blame of poor parenting and failed faculty leadership to the students attire. By making our students conform to the masses we are really relieving ourselves of the burden of good early parenting!! Such a shame really, because without demonstrating good parenting to our kids at the home front, they surely will not be capable of passing those values to their own kids in the future. 
 
 My daughter is a bright girl (trying not to toot my horn here but my kids are the only example I can draw from) whom has been in the schools "gifted and talented" program since 1st grade. She moved onto intermediate school (3-5) where she made honor role every semester, played in the band, attended dance classes after school along with the schools "Just say No" program. My wife and I have adopted a parenting approach that allows her to make choices, express herself and question things that she feels are wrong or inappropriate. In doing this we have found her to be a very logical and calculated thinker that knows her limits and the difference between right and wrong. Now, don't get me wrong!! It's a process that started long before this year. She is more "guided" than free to make random, unchecked final decisions. But more and more as time goes on.... she needs less and less input from us while coming to the same desired outcome. My point?...
 A uniform dress policy would not be needed if more "parenting" were being done for the kids that have caused our school district to believe this policy is needed!!
